description.text:
I made the CoilBot because I had a need for properly wound electromagnetic coils, without having to spend forever winding them by hand. This project was for fun and built in the span of a weekend a VERY long time ago. You can download the STL files from Thingiverse here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334983 Key features:
  • 2x16 LCD.
  • 3 Selection push buttons.
  • 2 Stepper motors.
  • Saves up to 3 presets.
  • Can fit every standard spool size.
  • Power Requirements: 1A @ 12VDC - 16VDC.
  • Controlled by an Arduino Uno.
  • Stepper Motors driven from Easydrivers available from Sparkfun.
  • Designed and rendered in AutoDesk Inventor 2014 Student.
    • More info:
    http://www.kyleorourke.com/coil-bot/ My Website:
    http://www.kyleorourke.com

comments.text: Nice!  One question, though - is there anything special about the spool spacer that makes the file so large?  If not, any chance you could share the dimensions so I can make one small enough to not crash my slicer?  :)
comments.author: soychicka

comments.text: The spool spacer is just a cylinder used to put the coil at the correct distance from the stepper motor. I think I had Autodesk on some kind of super high res setting when I exported it. The dimensions are as follows: Inner hole is slightly larger than the diameter of the metal shaft of the stepper motor around 5.25 mm. The disk is 6.5 mm tall and has an outer diameter of 22 mm. I would advise only using this as a reference design though... The code and overall functionality are pretty limited and incomplete as I built it in High School for a senior project =P

description.text:
One seed piece and eight tile pieces form a pseudo-random pattern.  
This is a physical implementation of the Rule 30 Elementary Cellular Automaton discovered by Stephen Wolfram and used in Mathematica as a pseudo-random number generator.  
This puzzle demonstrates the random and arbitrary nature of mathematics.

Print
  • one copy of big-bang-v2.stl
  • as many copies as you want of rule-30-cells-v2.stl
    • Starting with the "big bang" piece, complete a row at a time so that all inward pointing arrows are filled and the only free outward pointing arrows point downward into the next row. Keep printing copies of rule-30-cells.stl and extending the puzzle. This is your life now.

More on Rule 30:
http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Rule30.html Source code and more information about these tiles on my blog:
http://www.logarithmic.net/pfh/blog/01400409242
Updated 11 June 2014: Slight refinement to shape stops entire row from being flipped.

title: Buck & Doe Pendant modded into Prom Tickets

description.text: We took the buck & doe pendant found on the internet, re-created the design in Inkscape, modified it to use as our prom tickets (theme: A Night in the Wilderness) and extruded it in FreeCAD.

The buck and doe fit so well together you can print both pieces in ABS on top of each other (put together) and they easily snap apart after printing. Or print them separately in different colors and they fit together without any sanding. We also printed in Laywood-D3 wood filament at 190C but the print was slightly 'fatter', and required about 10 minutes of sanding to get the doe and buck to fit together. Our original plan was to print the doe at 190C and the buck at 230C for contrasting darkness of wood, but the buck came out even 'fatter.' We sold our dark-colored bucks as singles. We soldered copper hoops at the top hole so the pendant would lie flat against the chest when hung by a chain. Printing at scale of 1 was a bit large, 0.5 was too small, and 0.81 (50% volume) was just right, in our opinion. Our best prints were sliced in Slic3r with the following settings:
0.2 thickness
4 perimeters
25% fill
6 top solid layers (for solid finish)
4 bottom solid layers When printing with Laywood-D3, the bottom of the heated bed gives an almost varnished finish. We started printing the tickets upside-down for this effect. We uploaded all our files for your editing enjoyment!

title: Windshield trim screw insert for 1991 Civic/CRX

description.text:
This is plastic insert that lets self-tapping trim screws easily thread into sheet metal panels. It snaps into a square hole 10mm wide and anywhere from 12mm to 20mm long. It is intended to be a drop-in replacement for (and thus is closely modeled after) Honda p/n 91517-SH3-003, which is used on 1991 model year (and possibly '88-90 as well) Civic hatchback, sedan and CRX models to attach the trim panel at the base of the windshield.
I'm sure this seems like the most random part to upload, but I whipped up this substitute after getting frustrated with the old stripped-out, disintegrating parts on my car and thought I would share. The other option would have been to drop $25 and wait a week or two for OEM parts to arrive. That is, assuming they're still available.

comments.text: Just to let you know, there is a similarly-sized part in the standard arsenal of Ace hardware parts replacements that will work in a pinch for that plastic piece (ask me how I know) but printing yourself saves even a trip to the hardware store.

description.text: A demonstration of a technique for printing two part molds for box-like objects.

This is mainly a demonstration of a technique for making molds of things with flat bottoms (like boxes), and not too useful otherwise (unless you want the exact box I made). Some helpful notes:
  • Model the object you want to create, then subtract it from a solid to get a mold negative. No overhangs or undercuts.
  • Leave the top open; that will be your flat bottom.
  • Add flanges to the bottoms, both to give yourself somewhere to put some indexing features (I used mortise and tenons with a 0.2mm clearance), and to give you some leverage to pry the molds apart without having to push on the plaster.
  • Don't forget to add some draft to your mold, or you will have a hard time getting it unmolded. I used ten degrees on all sides.
  • Hollow out the bottom to save on printing time; the bridging won't be on the plaster side so its quality doesn't matter.
  • Try to avoid having interior curves on overhanging walls (like I have), or be confident you can print them without dropping threads to the inside.
  • Johnson's Paste Wax is a good mold release agent when using PLA and plaster.
    • The cast in the photos is my first attempt, so don't laugh too much at my poor casting technique.

comments.author: meva999

comments.text: Just a thought you might want to look and see what the CNC guys thing about using thrust control on either side of the rod.  typically its bad because the rod can not expand as it heats up.. normally a double thrust bearing at the drive side then just a radial bearing that the shaft can float in on the non driven side.
comments.author: xochal

comments.text: So do they spring load the bearings on one side?
comments.author: xochal

comments.text: i dont understand why they would spring load?  they do preload is they are using angular contact bearings for thrust control.  one side has a double thrus bearing or two angular contact bearings so it can take thrust in both the positive and negative directions relative to its axis the other side (non driven)  just "slip fits" thru a radial bearing that was there is no restraint in the plus minus direction.  keeps the shaft turning true but eliminates binding due to expansion.  also precision rod is a must when double supporting.   the X axis on both my lathes are only supported on the "driven" side.  (manual lathes)  CNC zone is a wealth of info on CNC setups.

The repeat for the other side.

This is a basic Hub for the just released Nylon 3D Printing Line.

Print 2 each with general settings.
Slot plastic shell for center rod and wire tie to hold the two sections. With the pliability of Nylon we are designing a newer spool and a couple new packaging forms for reduced overseas shipping costs. For additional information, see taulman3D.com

comments.text: So how does this function as a 'hub'? The coil of filament comes in a plastic shell that doesn't have a hole in the middle, so it can't function as a "spool" that I can see. This shape looks like it might fit onto the two plastic bumps in the shell, but the bumps are conical, so this wouldn't snap onto them, and there's no hole in the middle, so I don't see how this would work as a 'hub'. What am I missing?
comments.author: laird

comments.text: After some testing, the answer to "how does this function as a hub" is "extremely badly". The problem isn't really this "hub" - the real problem is that the filament isn't tightly would onto a spool, it's loosely looped into the plastic shell. This means that when the printer pulls the filament out, the spool doesn't rotate. Instead the filament pulls from one spot (stuck in one spot by the "lips" on the shell) with the filament inside the shell pulling tighter until it can't be pulled any more.

5 Degree of Freedom Arm
This project is intended on being an educational project so kids can learn about robotics. Originally I intended on having it controlled by servos and a microcontroller but realized that may have been a bit complex for the age group I was designing it for. After this project, I may expand on it to aim it at a more advanced group.

Very basic 5 DoF Arm. Still in progress. Current version 0.3 as of 11/1/12 The motors are purchased from http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/180 I might get more powerful motors or servos as one of the motors cannot support the entire weight of the arm so whenever power is cut, it will drop to its local equilibrium point. I used these switches https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10545
Pushing up would turn the motor clockwise, pushing down would turn the motor counterclockwise I included one of these switches just for fun. Everybody loves missile switches!

Inspired by Adam Savage's multitool belt holster, I decided to print something in the same spirit. This is designed for a Victorinox SwissTool Spirit X, but can be customized for other tools.

Print as plated, without supports.  
Can be customized to work with different tools; you will need to measure your tool with calipers, or scan it with a flatbed scanner and count pixels. There is a narrow end (the bottom), a wide end (the top), and a transition area between them you can specify. If your tool is slightly asymmetric, as is the Spirit, use the wider side to determine the transition points. The belt clip can be resized and moved up and down.  
Allow for maybe a millimeter of clearance on each side, and more for thickness if you have saggy bridging.

description.text: For auto bed leveling, if you have problems with repeatability, because of temperature swings, this may be the thing for you.

The SG-90 servos is not very precise, especially not when the temperature around it varies a lot, which it does when you switch between printing PLA out in the open, and ABS inside a closed chamber.  
With this bracket, the arm hits a mechanical stop when extended, making repeatability way better, than if you just relied on the servo to position the arm the same place each time it extends.  
Retract and extend angles is 0 and ~55 degrees.

I'm working on making 3D printable machines, objects that together can form working machines from scrounge-able parts united by 3d printed goodness.  I figured that the first step would be to make a motor complete with control circuitry, and the best motor seemed to be the stepper motor.  So here we have it, a (nearly) working stepper motor!

comments.text: This is brilliant perfect for demonstrating steppers to students!
comments.author: eoinjordan

comments.text: I just uploaded version 12 which I will print when my printer gets back home.  I have all the electronics this time, especially the power transistors which are important, and the bobbins have cores so yeah it's looking good so far that this motor will actually work.  I started creating a circuit board for the driver which is 3d printed and works a bit like old wire-wrap tech but different.  I plan to eventually build machines of this motor such as a robotic arm (!) and sell kits of them to fund my 3d printing.
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: It works... a little bit.  With the skateboard bearing and three NPN transistors per bobbin, the motor is barely able to slowly spin the rotor 1/8 of a turn, or in other words half way from one pole to the next.  This will be greatly improved in future versions with a smaller bearing for far less friction, paperclip cores on the bobbins, and an appropriately selected power transistor from Adafruit.  Then it should spin freely and have a very small work output to the drive shaft, which is all we need for light duty machines.  This is going to work, give it another month or two.
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: Regarding concerns of heat and effectiveness, if the thing spins at all, we can use it to do some interesting form of 3d printing.  I'm imagining all kinds of designs, well two or three myself, but all the creative people of the world making machines that 3D print something, anything of interest.  One machine is a pendulum that gravity feeds particle mixtures to be bonded by heat or other action.  Another is a glass etching device that uses a glass cutter as the print head... all made with natural materials including the  PLA.  Neat fun to do.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have been considering the heat issue. I found lots of good information at the reprap site: http://reprap.org/wiki/Stepper_motorhttp://reprap.org/wiki/Stepper... ... I think we can probably prevent most heat issues by running it at a low current and air cooling the motors. Most store bought motors are nearly solid blocks of metal with no airflow at all. A plastic motor with good airflow might be ok. Another idea is using water cooling. Run some channels through the design, hook up some aquarium tubing and allow water to keep it from getting too hot. I'm sure there are plenty of ways to confront this problem. In fact I think it's less of a problem and more of a challenge. The fun is in MAKING it work.

Keen observation on that trade-off, psyberjock.  And yes, I agree that's the way to go.  Truth be told i'm going to be happy if this "motor" functions well as an "actuator" or even just an "indicator".  The question is how much torque can we get out of an air core stepper motor.  Will it be more like a compass or a motor?  10% of motor strength if lucky?  I dunno.
comments.author: psyberjock

comments.text: 3D printed parts are notoriously tricky to print water tight... water + electrons probably ain't the best idea for cooling with 3D printed parts. Airflow is probably the safest bet here really.
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: This is very interesting. take it this makes the motors scalable should be useful, looking forward  to seeing a finished working prototype.
comments.author: Creative_Hacker

comments.text: Cool, glad you like the project.  It's extremely exciting to have three people helping me build and test the concept.  We will almost certainly get it tested properly soon this way.
comments.author: Creative_Hacker

comments.text: Version 6 is posted now.  I made the whole thing elliptical.  Its missing a cylindrical piece to join the two parts of the Lid, but I'm exhausted and need some downtime.  Other than that, I think it's a buildable motor.  I also added some OpenSCAD/Balancer photos for reference.
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: I am still making changes.  I have decided to make the rotor be an ellipsoid to remove some of the corners and edges.  I think wear and heating will be issues, so I'm adding cooling vents where possible and rounding off all the moving part corners.  I also removed the rotor keys (the magnet can do the aligning).  I'll post when ready.  Simple is good.
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: OK it's posted, version 5.  The rounded rotor turned out well, I'm happy with it so far!  But will it work?  Time will tell...
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: I just simplified the design and bumped the revision up to four.
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: I'm looking forward to the electrics plans. I'd love to build one of these. I could start banging out 3D printers for my friends if I can get these to work!
comments.author: psyberjock

comments.text: Note also that I have now constructed a driver board.  It has an ATtiny85 processor with Arduino programming, two LM358 opamps, and some LEDs plus a few caps and resistors, plus some connectors eventually.  The setup will be similar, each stepper gets one and they are driven by a central controller.  Oh, some protection diodes on the opamp outputs also.  It may be unconventional to drive stepper coils with opamps, I'm strange that way but I think the feedback of the opamps may squelch transients (maybe).  I plan to make many different driver schematics over time so that someone in the third world can make their printer work with whatever they can scrounge up.  This may require some unconventional design approaches.
comments.author: psyberjock

comments.text: We are planning to build one here soon.  The goal is to make an all-PLA printer to help people in impoverished countries to enter the world economy.  They have the natural resources to grow corn and make PLA from it, but buying imported stepper motors is impossible for them.  If we convert as much as possible of the printer to PLA then we may be able to make a significant impact in many peoples lives. And yes, all your friends can have one too!
comments.author: psyberjock

comments.text: Everything is looking great! I'm really impressed by your effort and goal. If there is anything I can do to help, let me know. I can certainly build one of these and test it out.

My dad used to make these for us from wooden balls when we were kids, but we got 3D printers now so this is a more modern version ;o)   
This one is a little different than the other animals, the printed parts are still pre assembled but you need to put some threads on it to finish the toy afterwards. Use something breakable to assure kids safety.   
The print is pretty easy because the support is already included in the file. Like always, if you print it out I would love to see the results :o)

Be kind and use PLA. It prints in about 4 hours using these settings.
Layer height: 0.15 mm
Bottom and top: 0.6 mm
Shell: 0.5 mm
Infill: 25%
Speed 75 mm/s - 100mm/s for the infill All the parts are hollow to create double walls for extra strength.
The support doesn't touch the model but there is a gap of 0.2mm so the print skips one or two layers to have the support snap of easily after printing. There are holes on top of the head and body and in the foot parts to attach the threading/wires to connect it to the controller piece.

description.text:
These tokens are often collected by gamers for use with other games. I wanted a nice, neat way to store mine on my game shelf. This is my first public design -- constructive criticism is welcome! It's not perfected. The corners lift when printing (not a problem with the design, but with my build platform), and if you tip the box too far, some characters fall out of the base wells (looking at you, Land Shark). Look for v2 when I've had a chance to test some different tapes. UPDATE: I've uploaded v2 of the box. Deeper pawn slots, and a shallower wedge box. I've added hold-down discs to the corners, which helps.

Lid - https://tinkercad.com/things/9dSbfb606Ht
Box - https://tinkercad.com/things/l2ijGVcxNso
Print one each of the box and lid. At low or medium resolutions, the lid should hold fine by friction.

A customisable glasses case that was designed to be very slim over the profile of my sunglasses in my pocket.  
My glasses are a nice snug fit, shape can be customised for yours with a quick edit of the OpenSCAD file. Lots of comments to show you where to tweak bits.  
Print these parts with 0% infill and no solid top layers. I use 3 perimeters with a 0.3mm nozzle.

Two ways you can use this Thing:
1.) Print the STL file as is, 0% infill, no top layers
2.) Customise this for your own specs, details below. Start by taking a bit of card and cutting a hole that your glasses slide through nice and snugly. Next step is to put that shape into a polygon in OpenSCAD (code is commented to say where). This involves a lot of Minkowski sums, which can take a long time to render, so be patient!

comments.text: I am somewhat at a loss as to how I use a piece of cardboard to describe a polygon in OpenSCAD. How does this step work?
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text:
Fair question. Given that this design is a prism with wiggly sides, the shape of that prism base is vitally important to give a good fit for your glasses.
The way I did this was to get a bit of cardboard (thin stuff from the side of a cereal pack) and used a stanley knife to cut a hole that I could pass my glasses through. Once I had this shape in the cardboard I measured the shape of it (some graph paper could help here) and wrote those co-ordinates into OpenSCAD.
If you're changing the polygon shape, be sure to modify the Friction Lock section. Hopefully I'll get around to updating this part to make that bit a bit more simple.
Good luck!
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text: I am afraid I do not understand how to plot an outline in this way, but I do have another suggestion: would it be possible to remove the bulk of the code so that you are left with a very quick way to play with the dimensions and perhaps print a small test piece?
comments.author: rpcook

comments.text: I think what you're describing is a polygon with a Minkowski sum of a cylinder. This could be printed with a thin shell and no infill. Wouldn't take much material to make this test piece. Do you need a hand writing this code?
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text: Nope, thanks! I just mashed around in the code until figured out how to extract the poly to a new document, then made changes until I understood how it worked. A couple of 45 second test prints allowed me to iterate quickly, until I got it right. Given as you wrote this in OpenSCAD would it be possible for you to use the Customizer to create a more consumer-friendly interface?

description.text:
14.5" x 14.5" Chess Board with a compass rose inlayed in the center. 
Designed to be made from 4 different hardwoods (see concept pic).
The brightly colored sample pic was scaled down and cut out of 4 different colors of hardcard, and then glued together onto a piece of foamcore.

After cutting out the board, I realized that the center ring with the alternating triangular pieces of wood were very difficult to work with. Next time I would just make that ring a solid color-- it worked the way it is designed, it just took a lot of work with a set of tweezers to glue down the hard word.  
After cutting out the pieces, you should glue them down to another piece of wood and finish it. I also tried clamping the pieces in between two pieces of plexiglass and that turned out pretty cool (sorry, I don't have any pics).

title: Aeroplane Cookie Cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a continuation of my cookie cutter series and is of a vintage WWII style aeroplane.

Since this is a cutting object and you will be applying pressure to cut through the cookie dough I suggest using no less than 40% infill, and really 50%-75% may be needed if you have the spare material handy. If using 40% infill use the honeycomb design as it is the strongest with the least amount of material (Bees have known this since the beginning of time).
I added a repaired version but in reality the original had nothing wrong with it but when saving to the STL format it seems to have brought in minor issues (nurbs to triangles). Basically the STL format goes wonkers with minor issues while being translated from nurbs to triangles so any high definition models come with minor issues.

title: Prusa i3 Rework Extruder Additional Fan Mounts Customizable

description.text: I am moving this design off of Thingiverse in protest of their attempt to patent designs originally conceived by the 3D printing community. This file can be found on Github at https://github.com/aBrainDump/Prusa-i3-Rework-Extruder-Additional-Fan-Mounts-Customizable For more information, please see the following article: http://www.openbeamusa.com/blog/2014/5/22/stay-classy-makerbot

Add one or two additional fan duct mounts to the extruder hotend mounting screws (15mm center to center). I wanted to add a print cooling fan duct http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217253 to my Prusa i3 Rework Extruder Upgrade http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:291291. But the extruder has only one fan mount and I need that to cool the all metal Hexagon hotend. To add an additional fan I created this adapter that mounts on the hotend screws and provides a pivot point. This allows you to add two additional fans to this extruder by mounting one on the left and one on the right of the hotend. This is customizable.
Printed in PLA .3mm layers

author: raykholo

title: Animatronic conforming Hand with Opposable Primate Thumb

description.text:
This is a single 3D printed Conforming Animatronic hand with an "Opposable" Primate thumb.
It uses Fly-By-Cable wires to activate each finger , thumb and knuckle joints.
UPDATE 20140627 :- Programming with Python (Fail however Hilarious video) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-JDAUVyp1m8&feature=share&list=UUcxve9G8bHCBBKE5kaW_okg&index=2
UPDATE 20140525 :- New Video "Servos Connected" http://youtu.be/tQKDYhN_IPk
Full Build Instructions can be found here :-
http://letsmakerobots.com/robot/project/opposable-thumbs-3d-printed-robot-hand.
Each cable can be operated individually or in combination to animate the hand either manually or autonomously with Hobby Servo control.

I set myself a task to create a single 3D printed hand with an "Opposable" thumb.
If you would like to build this then check my Video here first, it will run you through the basic build .....
http://youtu.be/SGr5lzFcyWQ
Full Build instructions :-
http://letsmakerobots.com/robot/project/opposable-thumbs-3d-printed-robot-hand
The design I present here comes from some of my previous jointed finger experiments.
First version (blue one) was made with normal PLA just for a feel of the concept.
Second version was made with Flexible PLA and I would advise this for full flexibility, for best results choose a low Z axis increment ie 0.1 mm ... this will give the base part may cross layed layers to help with strength and durability.
Also with 0.1mm the cable tubes are stronger.
If you are using flexible PLA then i also suggest you use 100% infill as this also helps strengthen the cable tubes.
Basic hand has a backplane , the flexible_ish part.
The cable/ligament trunking runs hide the cables.
The cable ductings carry the Fishing Gut from wrist to finger tips/opposable thumb and knuckles.
I used a flatbed scanner to freeze my hand in time and imported it into blender "Images as Planes"
(just remember to activate this command under user preferences.....then be sure to select the texture button so the image appears)
Its then an easy job to use the Bezier curve tool to plot points around the outline of the hand.
The Curve was then converted to a mesh and extruded along the Z axis - and this was the basis of its creation.
The cable runs were done almost the same way ....
Yes the normal PLA version worked however it had limited movement....so... I designed a second version for flexible PLA.
Cables were threaded through the ductings and secured at the fingertips,opposable thumb and knuckles.
...and a few test hand positions proved its concept.
To help with the springback of the fingers after activation I coated on the back thin tracks of elastic silicon sealant,
this worked wonders and gave a good realistic action.

title: Mendel Prusa ~ Max ~ Prism Y-carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Printer webcam: tinyurl.com/97uglwz Another y-carriage design using my unbreakable LM8UU bearing holders.
Designed for 150mm linear rod spacing and measures 175mm x 125mm overall.
Fits on a 200mm x 200mm printer bed. Includes clamps for XL/T5 belts, T2.5 belts and 3mm pitch GT2-3 belts. Designed for my Open-Beam Prism printer under construction http://www.nzec.co.nz/r3dwood but will work with Prusa, Mendel Max etc.

Print out one carriage and 4 x bearing holders.
The carriage STL file includes clamps for XL/T5 belts.
If you are using T2.5 belts you will also need to print out T2-5_clamps.STL.
If you are using GT2-3 belts or other 3mm pitch belts print out the GT2_3_clamp.STL. You will need 4 x LM8UU bearings and 8mm linear rod to suit your printer. Mount your print bed heater as usual ie:
230mm x 230mm x 6mm thick aluminium plate - mount the carriage directly to the plate then mount the print bed heater to the aluminium plate via 4 x 3mm machine screws (M3 x 20mm) plus springs and thumb wheel adjusters.
Refer to the last few photos to see how this is done.

I strongly advice running it through meshmixer first, deleting the stranded geometry and generating your own support material.

Made this standoff for the Hovership MHQ build (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251002), because I couldn't find any standoffs for it locally or quickly. I tinkered with these a bit and they seem to stick to the baseplate fairly well, but if you're still having problems you can try using a raft. You can Tap these with a M3 Tap if you want it looser and easier to screw in. For a firm fit though I just take a M3 bolt (at least 10mm long) and just screw it in one side and then the other while holding the standoff with a vice-grip and then its tapped for the screw and still fairly tight. Its a good idea after you tap with a tap or use the screw to tap it to blow out the standoff to get rid of the plastic shavings and dust in there. These weigh in at about 0.5g each. My scale only weighs in 1g increments and it shows it as 0g.

I printed these on a Replicator 2. Black PLA 1.75mm
0.1mm Layer Height
50% Infill
2 Shells Weigh about 0.5g each

description.text:
A customisable version of the enclosure for the Duet electronics for the reprap Ormerod printer. Customisations include Overall depth for extra room
Extra mounts to allow better horizontal positioning
PC board can be separate from main mounts to allow enclosure mounting with PCB in place
Base can be solid or hollow (using original acrylic plate)
Wall near cables can be cut out or filled in
Ventillation holes
Cut out for aux 5v connector Optional extra are reset / erase pins and guides to allow these two on board buttons to be easily pressed without taking cover off

The supplied stl is for the version as illustrated. To customise just edit in Openscad the entries near the top of the file and export a new stl.  
The DuetEncMeasure scad is not needed but allows for measurements and comparisons against the reprap original Duet enclosure. This needs the reprap Duet-enclosure.stl file.  
As this one has the separate PCB mounts to the rail mounts it is not a straight replacement if using the acrylic for front and back.  
1) Saw of the external rail mount hole tab on the acrylic, retain as extra spacer.  
2) Trim off bottom of acrylic (with logo), about 3mm. This is to allow it to clear the new rail mount holes which are just below the PCB holes.  
3) Screw in PCB to new mounts and into the acrylic. This needs slightly longer screws as the PCB is stood off from the base of the enclosure. I used 12mm. The mount holes are made slightly smaller than clearance so that can be tapped if using a completely solid base. So either tap or clear out a bit to use with acrylic.  
4) Put on the 3 T nuts. I used the existing screws for these but countersunk would be better for internal ones. Use the acrylic from 1) as an extra spacer on the external tab and extra spacers on the internal ones to bring up to the level of the acrylic. FOr the right hand internal chose the hole to allow for extra postioning freedom. The one nearest the centre still makes for a rigid mount and allows the enclosure to be moved well away from fan.  
The optional reset pins and guides are designed to be used with the existing acrylic cover where there are already holes in the right place. The guides are intended to be super-glued onto the inside of the acrylic and make sure the pins locate over the on-board switches. The gudes need to be cut to length to suit the depth of the case. The height of the pins can be adjusted in the SCAD for different size cases as it is good to have the conical tip to make clicking the button positive.The reset guide can extend most of the way to the board. The erase guide needs to be much shorter else it will clash with the ethernet connector when trying to put the lid in place.

description.text:
This Eppendorf/Centrifuge tube holder is used for packing under nitrogen - flow of nitrogen goes into a downward-facing funnel. I put my samples into the tubes, put them in the rack under the funnel, wait for a few minutes for nitrogen to displace air from the tubes Then I close the tubes thus packing my moderately air-sensitive materials under nitrogen.
It was designed in FreeCad (see the file). In order to save material, use 0.1-0.2 infill settings. Good luck

author: gustavoconect

title: Model Rocket Guide Ring for cutting tubes

description.text:
This is just a simple ring to go around a model rocket body tube. Estes sells a kit like this, but that'd be expensive for a classroom, so if you need a dozen guides for cutting BT-50 tubes this might be better. WARNING: I only tested the BT-50 fit (I couldn't find another body tube in the house)
WARNING 2: My printer may need a different "FUDGE" factor than yours. If it's too tight or loose, open the scad and change the fudge. I was also thinking it'd be "easy" to make adapter rings to nest body tubes. Included in the scad is a function that has the different ID & OD sizes of the body tubes, so it'd be "easy" to pick an OD for one tube and an ID for another tube... This is NOT used in my full size Lego R2-D2, http://L3-G0.blogspot.com - he doesn't have the rocket jets

This is a simple nested cylinders project.  Apparently I love o-ring shapes.  The "useful" part of this project is that the function has the sizes for the inner & outer diameters of the various Estes model rocket body tubes.  
Just print one of the rings, though I only tested the BT-50 one.  Also if you need a dozen for a classroom or scout group or something, check the fit before printing the rest, tolerances for various printers seem to vary.  
If it's too loose or tight, adjust the FUDGE factor variable in the scad file and retry it.  Call the function with the BT size to print the appropriate ring.  
Just print the ring, slide it over your tube, and carefully cut along the intersection with your xacto knife.  Or mark with a pencil or whatever.  
You could put a little tape on the inside if it's too loose.

title: Mendel90 nozzle fan duct (90/360 open, for hexagon hotend)

description.text: The hexagon hotend which I have mounted to my printer has the wires leaving the heat block horizontally and for ease of maintenance I did not want to bend them upwards and fit them through the x-carriage. Therefore, I needed a nozzle fan duct which was open at the front. This is the design I came up with. It is a low profile fan duct similiar to many other designs, with the exception of a 90 degree cutout at the front, which leaves space for the wires of the hotend. The wire handling is IMHO better, particularly, when working on the hotend. Having a circumferential slot for the air outlets did not work well enough with the single 50mm fan I was using. Therefore, I use separate outlets which are directed down- and sidewards. Works quite well (see picture with 50mm calibration tower). Using the adapter bracket, the duct can be mounted to the standard Mendel90 fan bracket for the x-carriage. Additionally, I have mounted 100mm white led strip, which looks quite nice when in operation. It is powerd by 12V always on, which I need at the x-carriage for the hexagon isolator fan anyways. Credits to nophead for his excellent Mendel90 printer and polyhole library and to Chris Petersen for pie.scad (part or dotscad library - https://github.com/dotscad/dotscad) Update 2014-12-21: for the hotend insulator fan duct (grey, on top of nozzle fan duct), see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:603889

The fanduct prints quite easily. No supports are needed, but your printer must be capable of bridging. As the fanduct is almost completely hollow, it prints quite fast, despite its size.  
The bracket needs to be printed upside down.  
My print settings are: 0.4mm nozzle, 0.3mm layer height, 2 perimeters, 25% infill.  
The slot holes allow adjustment using the bracket.  
The scad file is parametric, so you can change any settings as required (e.g. 40mm fan).

comments.text: That sounds like a bridging problem. When you slice the part for printing, in repetierhost take a look at the first layer where the bridging occurs and make sure the bridging paths look ok, especially in the regions where the stringers occur. Sometimes it helps to rotate the part around z-axis and slice again to get a different, maybe even a better result. Other than that I can only suggest to try and remove the stringers afterwards. Additionally, although I haven't tried this, you could try and stack another fan on top of the first one.

table top spool holder
uses a M10 threaded rod, 2 x M10 washer and 3 x M10 nuts
the 48mm 'bearing' that is included, fits on a rrw 50mm spool
also added a 52mm 'bearing' for larger spools

• print table stand and 2 spool bearings of the same size
  • turn 2 nuts on the M10 rod on one end and tighten them so that the rod is a couple of mm from the table when inserted in the table stand (25-29mm)
  • put the m10 washer between the lower M10 nut and the top of the table stand
  • put a washer and one spool bearing on top of the 2 nuts
  • put the spool on top of the bearing
  • put the other spool bearing on top of the spool and tighten the spool and the holders with a M10 nut
  • in case that the threaded rod doesn't move freely in the 10mm hole of the table stand, you can clean the 10mm hole with a drill

As an exercise on learning SCAD and wanting a quick way to check my printer settings easily, I created this test object.  
The cube is 25mm on a side and contains two circular indentations which snugly fit a penny (n.b. both US and Canadian pennies have the same diameter).  One indentation is on the top and is labeled with at T.  The other indentation is not the side and has an inset cone.  
The two circular indentations allow quick visual verification that all 3 axes are equally well calibrated.  That is, if you insert a penny in both indentations and you have more than 0.5mm clearance in any direction, you can tell which one of your axes is off relative to the others.  You only need to bring out the callipers if you want to know how much adjustment to make.  
The cone serves two purposes - it tests that your printer's filament settings are handling an arch well and it reduces print time, since most of the cube is empty space.

title: Y Axis Vibration Damper for MakerFarm Prusa i3

description.text: The MakerFarm Prusa i3 suffers from the same ailment as most Mendel variants: the Y axis is noisy. The combination of the linear bearings on rigid rods with the bed stack of wood, heat bed and glass causes a loud, buzzing resonance at some feed speeds. These bearing blocks allow you to mount the LM8UU bearings to the bottom of the bed plate with Sorbothane to damp much of this resonance, significantly quieting the printer. To use these brackets, you will need to cut pieces of .1" Sorbothane sheet to sandwich between the bearing and the clamp, as shown in the photos. The tabs on the clamps fit into the existing laser-cut openings in the bed. It will be a tight fit; the the clamps are sized to hold the Sorbothane in 15% compression, as specified by the manufacturer for maximum performance. These bearings should be printed standing on one end, so the filaments are stretched around the perimeter for maximum tensile strength. Once printed in ABS, they will be flexible enough to open and insert the bearings and Sorbothane. I don't recommend PLA because it will be more brittle and may deform over time due to the heat from the bed. Snap the bearings into the plate and secure them with M3 screws and nylon locking nuts. The correct Sorbothane sheet can be purchased here: http://www.amazon.com/Isolate-It-Sorbothane-Acoustic-Vibration/dp/B0084EXBFA You need only three small pieces, so one sheet is enough for a lot of printers.
Be sure to print the clamps standing on end, for maximum tensile strength around the perimeter.

title: RAMPS LCD Spacer for MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v

description.text: The MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v instructions call for the LCD to be mounted to the frame with four M3 screws. If you tighten these screws down, they cause the PCB to flex. If you don't tighten them enough, they rattle and vibrate loose. These spacers fit between the PCB and the frame, allowing you to tighten the screws as tight as you like without damaging the PC board. I recommend using nylon locking nuts to prevent the screws from rattling loose over time. You may also find that the two PC boards can vibrate and buzz against one another. You may wish to solve this by sandwiching foam tape between them and between the front PC board and the frame to reduce vibration further. I prefer Scotch Extreme Mounting tape for these applications because it conforms well to irregular surfaces and it can usually be peeled off of PCBs and plastics later without making a mess. http://www.amazon.com/Scotch-414P-60-Inch-Extreme-Mounting/dp/B005SRECEU

title: Glass Slide Holder for CTC 3D Printer

description.text:
If you are like me you use glass slides with the build plate of your 3D printer. I oftentimes find it easier to slide glass plates in and out than having to clean and maintain the stock kapton and blue printers tape that come with my CTC 3D printer.  
At first, I was just setting my glass plates aside but then I thought why not have something where I can hold the glass plates on either side of my 3D printer. It would then be easier to swap them out for each print. They would also act as a small cover or barrier against any draft or gust for those sides.

Just print the STL on it's side using your material of choice. Print 4 copies (2 for each side of your 3D printer). Once made, the slide holder has a small overhang on one side that is designed to hook onto either side of the 3D printer build chamber. My settings when I print this "thing":
Infill: 20%
Shells: 2
Layer Height: .20mm
No support needed (use rafts optionally) As with the MMC Holder that I designed (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316472), I made this for my CTC printer with the hopes that it can also be used with Makerbot or clones that make use of wooden chassis. If anyone can confirm that this will also work on the newer Makerbots or clones with aluminum enclosures I would greatly appreciate it if you make a comment.

title: Improved Hexagon Cooling Fan Shroud System for MakerFarm Prusa i3v and i3

description.text: This improved cooling system for the Hexagon (NOTE: NOT Hexagon AO) hot end on the MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v mounts the fan behind the hot end to keep it out of sight and out of the way. It also directs the cooling airflow away from the part being printed and away from the heated bed to help prevent warping. This cooling system uses a 25mm fan mounted in the extruder deck behind the hot end to pull air up and vent it out the top, away from the print. A shroud around the hot end pulls air in through the front, across the cooling fins and into the fan intake. The (slightly) warmer air exits behind the extruder. The small fan only moves a small amount of air (3CFM) but this air is directed exactly where it's needed, to effectively cool the hot end, and not the print or bed. As an additional benefit, the hot end is fully visible from the front, so it's easy to monitor its temperature and detect leaks or other problems. You will need a 25x10mm fan that can generate around 3CFM of airflow. I used a 12V Sunon Maglev fan available here: http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/MC25101V2-000U-A99/259-1570-ND/2757808 It's quiet and generates plenty of airflow to keep the Hexagon hot end cool. This new X axis shelf is compatible with the wood parts from the original i3v kit, and it's also compatible with my Z probe servo mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335632 The shelf is also compatible with the i3, though the shelf brackets are different. If you have any trouble with the hot end melting the shroud, you can make an insulator with fiberglass strips and Kapton tape. See the photos.

Be sure to mount the fan so it pulls air up and vents it out the top. The fan may be mounted with 10-12mm M3 flat head screws. The mounting holes in the recommended fan are the right size to tap with an M3 tap so it can be mounted directly without nuts. Be sure to clean up the countersinks in the shelf to be sure the screw heads fit flush with the top so they don't interfere with the extruder. The fan shroud mounts to the underside of the shelf using the two existing extruder mounting screws and two more short (8MM or less) M3 screws at the back. The back holes are sized to tap with M3 threads. Depending on your printer, you may need to drill out the holes to 2.4mm prior to tapping. The deck is very flexible because there is not very much material connecting the two halves. Once the tabs are inserted into the X carriage, the fan shroud is mounted on the bottom and the hot end mounting plate and extruder are bolted to it, it will be very stiff. Note that the fan shroud is sitting about 2mm above the Hexagon's heat block, and over time it can soften and droop. You can prevent this by wrapping the bottom of the shroud in a couple of layers of Kapton tape. UPDATE: I used a strip of 1/16" woven fiberglass insulation wrapped in Kapton tape to make in insulator to place between the heat block and the shroud. See the photos for details. I've run this as high as 305C (printing polycarbonate) without any problems. The fiberglass insulation I used can be purchased from Mcmaster-Carr: http://www.mcmaster.com/#87965k14

At some point in the use of my CTC 3D printer, I kept getting annoyed at how unwieldy the filament string was. It didn't matter wether the filament was ABS or PLA. If you accidentally let go of the filament string during the changing process, the filament roll would unwind badly.  
I thought about putting a large metal clip on the top part that is used to mount the metal guide for the print bed. Then I thought of making these babies.

Just print the STL file on it's side or better yet print it upside down with the little "legs" sticking out in the air. Once printed, just like the picture mount on the top of your CTC 3D Printer on the wooden part that "mounts" the metal rods which guide your build platform. My settings when printing:
Infill: 20%
Shells: 2
Layer Height: .20mm Use supports if you are printing the STL as-is. I recommend turning it in Makerbot or Replicator G so that it is on it's side or upside-down with the legs sticking up (that way you do no need to print supports). You will need glue to make the installation permanent. On my printer I had to dab some on the filament guide between the stubby "legs". I often found that no matter how "snug" I made the part, the filament would eventually force it off the 3D printer unless it was glued on.

title: Z Probe Servo Mount for MakerFarm Prusa i3v for Auto Bed Leveling (HXT900)

description.text: UPDATE: Added longer version of Z probe for longer hot ends. This replacement X carriage bracket and switch arm allow you to mount a servo-actuated Z probe to your MakerFarm Prusa i3v printer. The Z probe serves two purposes: it registers the Z home off the glass (instead of the frame) and it allows the printer to probe in multiple locations and compensate for a bed that isn't perfectly level. Both require a newer version of the Marlin firmware. See details in the instructions. There are several versions of this solution out there. I designed this one because I wanted to tuck the switch up tighter under the carriage when it wasn't deployed. This is only for aesthetics. Note this part will not fit with the standard MakerFarm hot end fan shroud. It will fit with my improved Hexgon cooling system: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335613 The bracket and switch arm are sized for the inexpensive and readily-available Hextronic HXT900 servo, available here: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/RC_PRODUCT_SEARCH.asp?strSearch=HXT900 You can use the limit switch that came with the i3v kit. See the instructions for details. NOTE: this probe arm was designed around the Hexagon hot end. If your hot end is longer, you may need to use a spacer to raise the extruder and hot end up off the mounting shelf to get enough clearance to use this Z probe. Video of the servo probe in action: http://youtu.be/yazApS1ISxo

The servo fits through the hole in the bracket and is attached with the screws that come with the servo. Depending on your printer calibration, you may need to drill out the holes before installing screws. The servo horn that comes with the servo should snap into the arm and when mounted to the servo with a screw, it should be trapped in place and very rigid without any further attachment. If needed, a 2.04mm hole is provided and may be tapped to install an M2.5 screw through the servo horn to secure it to the arm. The limit switch may be mounted directly to the arm with M2.5 screws. The holes are sized to be directly tapped with an M2.5 tap so no other hardware is necessary. You can use the limit switch that came with the MakerFarm kit. You will need to remove the spring arm for the best accuracy. Just grasp it firmly with pliers and carefully twist it free from the housing. Be careful not to crack the body of the switch. If you find that the switch from MakerFarm requires too much force to actuate and it deflects the bed too much to get an accurate measurement, you can try this switch, which requires only 25g to activate, instead: http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?vendor=0&keywords=SW1005-ND&stock=1 To use the probe, you will need to upgrade and configure the Marlin firmware in your printer. Zennmaster has provided an excellent guide for setting up auto-bed leveling on the i3: http://zennmaster.com/random-things/auto-bed-leveling-for-the-makerfarm-prusa-i3-part-1-assembly-and-basic-setup

Bringing a duct under from the rear is one option. There's also room on the right, or in the usual position on the front. Stray air blowing into the front of the hot end shroud will only help. I'll probably be looking at this soon, but probably not this weekend. I've also got a belted extruder project in the works. The gear chatter is annoying me. Ironically, the chatter is worst when printing the GT2 pulleys for the belted extruder. :)

comments.text: One thought I had this morning: I have the parts designed so the switch arm tucks up to the rear.  This is aesthetically pleasing, but it means that the servo shaft is in the way of the extruder mount bolt.  You'll have to pull the two M3 screws and remove the left bracket to get at the screw.  You can print the mirror-image of the arm and flip the servo over so the switch comes up in the front.  This will provide clearance to get at the extruder screw with the arm down, but the switch will stick out the front a little.  Your choice.

description.text:
I wanted to experiment with 3D printing an object with a built-in spring. This clip is designed so that when the clip is closed there is still some force from the spring holding it shut (as you would expect from a spring clip).  
This is only a partial success: it works as expected, but if printed in ABS, the plastic will yield slightly when you open the clip, rather than being completely springy.  
ABS is simply not a good material for making functional springs, as the yield strength is too low. However, with a little more care in designing the spring, it should be possible to design this so that it stays within its range of elastic deformation all the time.
After printing, simply slide the two halves of the hinge together to assemble the clip and put some force on the spring.

comments.text: "ABS is simply not a good material for making functional springs".

This is a version of the chess set from glChess and the Linux xscreensaver hack called "endgame", which I first posted as Thing number 322616. That version had severe overhangs that could cause problems with all but the very best slicer software. This version changes all overhangs to less than 45 degrees, making the set more likely to slice and print without difficulty. The sole exception to the overhang rule is the knight, for which a manually-generated support has been designed. If you wish to try auto-generated support for the knight, the version without the support structure is also included. All pieces have been scaled correctly for a standard chess board size (that is, 25% larger than the original set posted).
Update May 20, 2014: The knight support structure was modified to reduce the gap between the support and the piece.

See the instructions for the original glChess set, thing number 322616. Instructions are basically the same. However, all pieces in this set are correctly sized (in mm), and all pieces are manifold. If you use the version of the knight that includes the support structure, then no additional support is required (all overhang angles are 45 degrees or less).
Pieces should be printed in groups, to prevent the extruder from dwelling on any single piece for too long, thus working over soft plastic and producing poor results. Since the extruder will tend to dwell on the tallest piece after all shorter pieces have finished printing, this set includes a piece called "cooling_tower" that is the same height as the king. Place the cooling tower as far away from the tallest piece (e.g., the king) on the platform, to allow a longer time for each layer of the tallest piece to cool, while the extruder is off drawing another layer on the cooling tower.

comments.text: How do I download the file so that I can edit and make changes on it before printing it?
comments.author: emersoncampbell

comments.text: This set was made just that way:  By editing the original source.  But for the actual source files, you'll need to go to Thing #322616.   Still, I found out by a lengthy investigation that the original source code (in C) parses data files which are in such a specific format that it's very difficult to rewrite the design data for anything else, even just to smooth out the facets a bit.  That's why I reworked the whole thing as "OpenSCAD Chess" (Thing #585218), which is much more amenable to going in and tweaking parameters.  Even then, some things like the queen's crown were hard enough to model that I just worked with the STL file, and then imported the STL into OpenSCAD.  The knight, of course, is all just STL mesh manipulation.

The RBG Shield from Adafruit Industries is great, but it's not an easy design to enclose, due to the close proximity of the buttons, and the various feature heights.  I have tried to address the button problem as best I can think of right now.  I may add faces to the buttons that can be glued on after the faceplate is assembled.
The design allows both CNC Router, and 3D printing.  It's a tight fit, so be sure to calibrate before (or after) printing.  Even with calibration, you may need to sand the LCD window a bit, as that part is not always of uniform dimensions.
The buttons will need to be cleaned up for best results.
If you have any recommendations on how to improve this design for mounting, please let me know your thoughts in the comments.
I print with 0.3mm layers, at 5% fill.  Two perimeter loops.  The reset button can be cut flush with the surface to avoid unintended resets.

description.text: This is a continuation of my cookie cutter series and is of a Groovy vintage VW Beetle style car.

Since this is a cutting object and you will be applying pressure to cut through the cookie dough I suggest using no less than 40% infill, and really 50%-75% may be needed if you have the spare material handy. If using 40% infill use the honeycomb design as it is the strongest with the least amount of material (Bees have known this since the beginning of time).  
I added a repaired version but in reality the original had nothing wrong with it but when saving to the STL format it seems to have brought in minor issues (nurbs to triangles).  Basically the STL format goes wonkers with minor issues while being translated from nurbs to triangles so any high definition models come with minor issues.

description.text: Lid for the Aquacopter Quadcopter.

I wanted the barometer sensor to still work for altitude hold so I made eye holes and used some Gore Tex Repair kit to stick over the eyes. I then used some silicone and put the eye rim's on top of the goretex. This should allow it to breathe but still keep water out. Printed with support, took ~8 hours on my makerbot replicator 2 for just the lid. I really should re-deisign it somehow to not have support. Note: I put a hole in the back for a Deans connector. I made a jumper that plugs in there so that i can take my time plugging the batteries in and wiring it all up. If I was to do it again I would move that hole to the left or the right side the front and back end up REALLY crammed on space with the wires coming from the naza. Especially the bulky GPS wire. So directions.
  • Print lid with support
  • Print shelves ( far left shelf piece is not needed that was something i was using during prototyping )
  • Cutout gore-tex eyes and stick in there. Use silicon or superglue or whatever to stick the eye border/rims on.
  • assemble. I used 12 m3x8 button head screws from ace hardware to attach the shelves.
    • Everything is a real tight fit i had to play with the shelve heights quite a bit. Mine is setup GPS, Receiver, Naza + naza VU unit... and it just barley fits.

comments.text: Brilliant idea using Gore Tex. How did it work out in practice? I am attempting to do the same thing with my APM + Aquacopter.

title: Super Typhoon Haiyan (Hurricane) from Suomi NPP VIIRS

description.text: Super Typhoon Haiyan observed from satellite Suomi NPP VIIRS Longwave Infrared Imaging Band I5 (significantly down-sampled), showing in brightness temperature.  Haiyan was one of the strongest tropical cyclones ever recorded.  This image was taken on November 8, 2013 over the  Philippines.  I just 3D printed one today with a size of 5cmx5cmx2cm.

To make this thing is relatively simple.  First, you find a image and make sure it is in "gray scale".  Very likely you will need to downsample it a bit so that it is small enough, say 200x200 rows and columns.  Then you probably need to smooth it using image processing software such as ImageJ or GIMP so that is doesn't have too many spikes.  Finally you generate the mesh using Matlab.  The key Matlab function to use is the 'meshgrid'.  And then write it out as .stl using 'stlwrite'.  Enjoy.

title: Prusa i3 Vanilla Adjustable Y Axis Endstop Holder

description.text: An adjustable Prusa i3 Y axis endstop holder I created using clefranc's thing:82631 and Valkyrie42's thing:288414 as inspiration. To learn more about my Prusa i3 Build visit: http://greymatterdroppings.com/category/3d-printing/

I used two 16mm m3 bolts and m3 nuts to hold the vertical slider to the frame holder.  
Then use two more 16mm m3 bolts to hold the mechanical endstop to the vertical slider.  
Note:  there are two m3 nuts that screw against the makerbot v1.2 endstop to create space for the wiring... then use two more m3 nuts to lock the endstop at the correct vertical height.

A "One Size For All" (almost?) Spool Roller, using 624zz bearings.
As I have now three size of spools, I finally rejoined the meme of using two separate bases in order to fit any width of spool :)

Print two.
Add for each :
4 624zz bearing
2 M4x25 bolt
2 M4 nut
4 M4 washer For the 603 model use M3 bolt/nut/washer instead For the 623zz model use :
2 M3x20 bolt
2 M3 nut

comments.text:
Wouldn't be enough two bearings for each base? I've seen lot of designs with only 2 bearings or even with printed tubes instead, it should work here. It would be a thiner part and you know, the less vitamins, the better ;) Very smart solution by the way, so simple and so effective!
And, for those who ask about connecting the parts, why would you do that? keeping them separated is the main point of this design, and thingiverse is full of already connected bases designs (thing: 46016, 283656, 236875...)

description.text: Spool holder for Felix printers with inner diameter of the spool 75mm. It uses one of the included bearing and two cradle like frame parts.

Star Citizen is a space sim being developed by Chris Roberts, RSI, CIG. This Origin Jumpworks 300i is derived from the current (May, 2014) Hanger Module in Star Citizen.
It has been scaled to a 180mm (7in) x115mm (4.5in) x42mm (1.7 in) profile.
The 300i is one of the initial flyable ships. This model has been modified for easier 3D printing. There are two ship files and both are identical profiles. Only one is needed.
SUPPORTED has cross bars to break up and make the exterior supports more rigid. If your exteriror supports run down the X-axis (180mm long) then this is the prefered file. GUNNED has no cross bars to break up the exterior supports. If not using exterior support OR your supports have modified parameters to assist in making them rigid, then the GUNNED version may possibly work better for you. Also included in a separate build profile are the Mass Driver and Lasers by themselves.
TWO (left and right) A&R Omnisky VI Laser
ONE Klaus & Werner Sledge II Enjoy, and happy printing. - DRUM out

Three files presented. 300-Supported: When exterior support was used, the 180mm lengths made them unstable. Cross bars were added to shorten the support runs and keep them rigid. 300-Gunned: Same as the Supported but minus the cross bars. Can be used if you have modified support parameters that would break up a long support run. 300-JustGuns: What it says. This can be used to remake them if the weapons fail when made with the ship. They are aligned, so if you wish to rotate them and print vertical it shouldn't be a problem. Used 20% fill and 4 wall thickness for print. Prefered size = 180mm+
STL Profile = 180mm
Smallest successful print = 100mm

comments.text:
Unsure what you are saying (asking?) Zelange. Printer supports are derived from your machine coding, not from the STL files. Usual selections are none, exterior or full. The need for support will derive from the object itself. If there are low hanging features you will need supports to build upon until the low feature merges with the base print, and long horizontal runs may at times need underlying support to prevent sagging.
The bottom of this ship is not flat, thus supports would almost be a given.
Another thing to consider is machine code speed options. The normal Slow, Standard, and Fast selections (related to machine head speeds) will affect the total print times but also directly relate to the quality of the finished print. - DRUM out

This filament spool holder uses 40 - 5/16in (7.9375mm) ball bearings.  The ninja version adds a 1.75mm track along the bottom where you can insert 1.75mm NinjaFlex filament to keep it from sliding around (see the picture of the black version above).  
Should work with a variety of spool sizes, narrow spools (<55mm wide) can be placed across the longer length, wider spools should be placed across the shorter width.  
If 5/16in bearings aren't available, you can probably scale the print slightly and use 8mm bearings.  
You should probably watch a while to see if it works with your spool before leaving it unmonitored.

Laser tube alignment brackets for the Buildlog.net 2.x laser cutter.  This version can be printed on a 3D printer with a 4" bed.

If you are making a Buildlog.net 2.x laser cutter, you can use these two brackets to hold the laser tube in alignment. They have been modified from the original to fit on a 4" printer bed. The source is a combination of DXF and OpenSCAD. You can adjust the printer size slightly using the parameters PW (printable width) and PB (printer bed). Both are sizes in millimeters. I made separate left and right brackets so the feet can stick out on opposite sides. It does not matter which bracket you use for which side. 2.x laser cutter: http://www.buildlog.net/blog/2011/02/buildlog-net-2-x-laser/
The original version of this part: http://www.buildlog.net/cnc_laser/erp/get_doc.php?docNumber=C17010 Attribution: The DXF file included was created by Bart Dring. The original is available from Buildlog.net.
